awd_titl_txt: Student Support for 2019 International Conference on Logic Programming
awd_abstract_narration:
This student travel grant is to enhance the education of selected US graduate students in the research area of Logic Programming. This will be realized by enabling them to attend the 2019 International Conference in Logic Programming (ICLP), which will include a logic programming Doctoral Consortium (DC) and a Fall School in Logic Programming (FSLP) for these students.  An important focus of the conference is to improve student education in the field of Logic Programming.  The conference organization and governance include many prominent researchers in the area. The conference will help nurture the next generation of ICLP researchers by enabling students to meet senior researchers at the conference and take part in face-to-face discussions with them.  

The proposed activity furthers technological advancement in the area of logic programming, which is currently seeing substantial industrial interest. ICLP has been the premier international event for presenting research in logic programming in areas including foundations, languages, declarative programming, logic solver implementation, and applications. Contributions are sought in all areas of logic programming.  Supporting the educational mission of the conference will bring long-term benefits to both industry and academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided funding to support the attendance of invited speakers and about nine students to the 35th International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP) 2019. The conference took place in Las Cruces, NM from September 20th, 2019 to September 25th, 2019. Surplus funding was then used to support US-based students to participate in ICLP 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023.

ICLP is the top conference in the field of logic programming. It has been organized yearly since 1982 and has always attracted a world-wide audience. ICLP 2019 was attended by 102 participants (96 registered and 6 NMSU students) from 16 countries; these participants are leading researchers of the field and around twenty exceptional doctoral students in logic programming and knowledge representation and reasoning. 49 participants are from the USA. Other countries and participants are Austria (7), Belgium (1), Brazil (1), Canada (2), China (1), France (5), Germany (5), Greece (2), Israel (1), Italy (9), Mexico (1), Portugal (1), Spain (13), Turkey (2), and UK (2).

Besides the main technical track, the conference featured four tracks (Application, Sister Conferences and Journal Presentation, Research Challenges in Logic Programming, and Women in Logic Programming), the Autumn School on Logic Programming, the Doctoral Consortium, and the logic programming contest. The technical program included five invited talks, three invited tutorials, thirty rapid communications, forty-four technical communications. Talks are grouped into thematic sessions such as epistemic logic programming, constraints & logic programming, semantics, applications, equivalence of programs, testing logic programs, efficient grounding, datalog, probabilistic logic programming, argumentation, planning system, analysis of logic programming, commonsense reasoning, languages, and action languages.

The conference featured the first ever special session on Women in Logic Programming with an invited talk and six presentations. 

This award funded and supported the attendance and participation of five invited speakers and four US-based graduate students, not including six at New Mexico State University who were given free registration. Participation in a premier conference of a field is an extremely important part of doctoral students’ academic careers as it provides them with opportunity to interact with more senior researchers and peers as well as to be exposed to leading edge work. The support from this award made it possible for the students to participate in the conference. The surplus funding of this award continued to support students, enabling thirteen students to participate in the three following ICLP conferences (ICLP 2020-2023).
